posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>180060952
>I've heard that stuff shot on film can basically be upscaled infinitely
You've misunderstood. Film doesn't need to be upscaled, because the original film negatives can just be scanned at a higher resolution. So if you're watching an older movie shot on film, you're most likely getting real 4K. CGI blockbusters shot on film from the 90s and 00s are an exception, because they're not going to re-render the old effects, which is why such films are upscales. This is why something like Lord of the Rings is an upscale despite being shot on film. But yeah watch something like Jaws, 2001, Lawrence of Arabia, classic Hitchcock kinos, etc. and it's all real 4K.

>>180049106
there's a point to be made here.
my youngest brother is about 7 years younger than me. he grew up with money, i didn't. i remember my parents arguing about money, the stress and anxiety of being broke and saving money anywhere we could. then my dad finished night school and got a new job when i was 13, and my brother was 6. life changing increase in salary, new house, debts cleared, suddenly taking vacations multiple times a year etc. my bro grew up in a family where money wasn't a problem and our parents were happy to spoil us every chance they got.

i care about money, i'm careful with it, i treat myself sometimes but i need to know i have something in the bank for emergencies or else i can't relax. i don't take stupid risks or spend excessively. my childhood was one of financial stress and anxiety, and that never left me.
in contrast, my brother is always broke, always quitting jobs because "his boss is an asshole", always travelling with friends with dad's money, and is always trying to borrow more from him and from me. he grew up not caring about money, and doesn't appreciate it how easy he had it, and still does. he's nothing like i was at his age, and i don't see any signs of him maturing or taking his career seriously.

tl;dr growing up with money can very easily make you spoiled and lazy, it may be too late for jackie's son but i appreciate the decision.

There's a plothole in Voyager that I haven't seen brought up anywhere.
In TNG (and even some Voyager episodes) the holodeck is able to accurately simulate starfleet personel, to the point where the holo version of Leah Brahms ends up saving the day by providing info only she would know about ship repairs.
So why don't the Voyager crew (who lost all their medical staff, for instance) create a med bay in the holodeck with holo versions of real starfleet doctors? Or create top tier holo chefs to cook food using the ingredients from the hydroponics bay. Or hell, simulate the entire starfleet admiralty, or all the captains to help discuss options out of seriously fucked up situations.
There is one episode I remember where they make a holo version of the doctor's backup repair program, but that's about it. It honestly takes me out of the show that they include a holodeck for shennanigans but no one thinks to use it for actual emergencies.

>>180062842
All of this could have been averted, and the show given some more realism and sense of loneliness, if they just decided to have the holodeck be non-functioning or too costly to use. I mean if they have to "ration" their replicator use, it makes no sense that they can use the holodeck so liberally.
It makes sense for the prestige flagship with over 1,000 people mostly on peaceful diplomatic and scientific trips to have a holodeck - it doesn't make sense for a small, undermanned ship on the other side of the galaxy, carefully having to manage resources at all times, to use the holodeck so much.

Just as humanity was rebuilding, they were then coerced into joining the weakest space elf faction to bolster their numbers.
Since then humans have been pushed into needless conflict and wars with other alien factions, and human culture has been manipulated to increase their passivity.
The mirror-universe is just that, a mirror, and one that isn't all that much darker than the main universe; all things considered.

posts.com:
>The killers of Eden or Twofold Bay killers[1] were a group of killer whales (Orcinus orca) known for their co-operation with human hunters of cetacean species. They were seen near the port of Eden in southeastern Australia between 1840 and 1930. A pod of killer whales, which included amongst its members a distinctive male called Old Tom, would assist whalers in hunting baleen whales.[2] The killer whales would find target whales, shepherd them into Twofold Bay or neighbouring regions of coast, and then often swim many kilometres away from the location of the hunt to alert the whalers at their cottage to their presence and often help to kill the whales.

>Old Tom's role was commonly to alert the human whalers to the presence of a baleen whale in the bay by breaching or tailslapping at the mouth of the Kiah River, which is one of the smallest rivers, where the Davidson family had their tiny cottages. This role endeared him to the whalers and led to the idea that he was “leader of the pack,” although such a role was more likely taken by a little known female (as is typical among killer whales).[2] The whale known as "Stranger" described as a leader of "stranger's mob" was a large 30 ft male.

>After the harpooning, some of the killer whales would even grab the ropes in their teeth and aid the whalers in hauling. The skeleton of Old Tom is on display at the Eden Killer Whale Museum, and significant wear marks still exist on his teeth from repeatedly grabbing fast-moving ropes.[2]

>In return for their help, the whalers would anchor the carcass overnight[4] while the killer whales ate the tongue and lips of the whale, then haul it ashore.[2][3] The arrangement is a rare example of mutualism between humans and killer whales.[2] The arrangement was called "the law of the tongue".[3] The killer whales would also feed on the many fish and birds that would show up to pick at the smaller scraps and runoff from the fishing.

A friend’s apartment is disgustingly unclean, wet old food mold growing on cooking pans,

Did a deep deep cleanup.
My apartment is literally spotless — dishes washed the moment I’m done using them. Routine sweeping and wiping. Trash is covered with a lid and taken out twice a week.

German cockroaches were decimated from seeing about 80 per day to about 8 per day within the first 3 months.

Started using poison bait traps took it down to seeing about 3 per day after about a month of treatment.

Hired a professional who put 10x the amount of poison bait, sticky paper, metamorphosis disrupters, and diatomaceous earth powder — this will continue for 12 months. >>180052611
Probably not, I'm co-owner of a company I founded with a business partner.

You probably don't even know that cabinetry voids are the number one harborage area for spiders inside the home (excluding garage). Bathroom, kitchen, etc. Run your hand underneath the lower edge of the cabinets and you'll find hollow gaps between cabinet sections and wall. Those voids are the prime hiding spot. Spiders have book lungs which have multiple exposed openings along their thorax, so a pesticide dust application is best. I use an Exacticide gun to blow Tempo dust into those voids, and also inside window frames and the blinds mechanisms.

That'll be $150+tip. I'll be back once every 3 months to treat the home exterior and property to prevent future infestations.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>180053564
Nope. Bugs are attracted to the environmental conditions of the home. The home is cool when it's hot out, warm when it's cold, dry when it's wet, and moist when it's dry. Bugs will enter the home regardless of how clean and tidy it is seeking moisture, safety, etc.

That said, it also depends on the outside environment. If you're in the middle of a rocky, wind-swept badlands with little vegetation, there's not going to be a lot of bugs in the local area to be a problem. But if you're in a place generally agreed upon to be desirable or hospitable, you're gonna have bugs eventually. Rodents, too. Pests in general.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Season 1 was perfect. Survival playing a huge role made every episode feel engaging, the island really felt like a character of its own, the way all the flashbacks culminate in the finale, how we learn about their troubled past, how we see their struggles making it onto that flight only for it to crash, really selling the point that it was fate that brought them all together. Season 1 was the only season with consistently good flashbacks. The god tier cliffhanger of the hatch and WAAAALT. It was perfect. I love season 1 so much.

Season 2 has some of the best additions in terms of lore but hasn't held up as well on rewatch because the filler is rough and its the worst kind of filler where the writers insult your intelligence by trying to make it seem meaningful when its not, filler that doesn't even explore its characters in any interesting way, its just there to seem like something exciting might be happening but it never does. The hatch may just be the peak of the show and the beginning and end of season 2 is excellent, a lot of the material in-between however is not great. Still a good season though

Season 3 is definitely better than 2 is, its more consistent, while there's still filler in 3, its done better, episodes like "Tricia Tanaka is Dead" is filler done in the best possible way, that said "Stranger in a Strange Land" is worse than any episode from season 2. I'd say the weakest part about season 3 is the island material in the first 7 episodes, all of it feels like filler because the writers were clearly more focused on hydra island at the time. But once Kate escapes and we get "Flashes Before Your Eyes" the island starts getting more interesting again, then of course there's the barracks and the various dharma stations. I love season 3, its flawed for sure but still great fun. Also one of the most legendary twist endings of all time.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>180064120
Season 4 is focused and to the point, with only a couple of episodes that feels like they waste your time. The new characters worked great, even their flashbacks were enjoyable. It's a decline in quality from a lore and character perspective though, but as a season centered around finally leaving the island I think it did a good job.

Season 5 is where the show officially jumps the shark but I can still find enjoyment in it if I turn the critical thinking part of my brain off. Time travel is dumb fun and the 70s dharma storyline is comfy. Them ending up being responsible for the very incident that is responsible for the plane crash is a bit of clever writing, even if it is kind of dumb at the same time.

Season 6 is not enjoyable at all. 80% of the season is filler and the writing is dogshit, all of the island material is shit and the flash sideways was only exciting the first time you watched them.

1 > 3 > 4 = 2 >> 5 >>> 6

>>180054743
I've watched less than 7 godzilla movies so I cannot. But I liked all the ones I watched.
>Godzilla (1998)
First Godzilla film I ever saw, was 6 years old, loved it but had to keep it secret from my cool-kid friends.
>half of an unknown Godzilla vs. Ghidora film
Was in a dentist's office waiting room as a kid. Didn't really understand why Godzilla looked so different, but Ghidora was cool as hell.
>Godzilla (2014)
Instant classic, done very well.
>Shin Godzilla (2016)
First jap Godzilla I watched completely. A complete shift in narrative and tone from the american ones I'd seen, fantastic orchestra and climax made it one of the most memorable to me.
>Monsterverse
Great americanized action flicks, did justice to my boy Ghidora who I saw for the first time since that day in the dentist office.
>Godzilla (1954)
Was inspired to watch the original after Shin. I went to a few threads like these first to make sure I had the right expectations going in. Oddly enough, it was the first time I recognized the actual og Godzilla score that's been used in every single Godzilla movie since (except 98 and Shin I think). I love that score, and ultimately I really enjoyed the movie, especially the pacing, the build up over time and the human characters. The sets were surprisingly better (to me) than many of the middle era jap films I haven't watched. It was interesting to see where the Oxygen Destroyer used in Monsterverse came from as a concept. In og, it's a terrifying WMD the creator is horrified to see brought to mankind, for the consequences and parallels to the atomic bomb used in Japan only 9 years prior to this movie. Most of the japanese audience was alive to see those bombs used on their nation. In Monsterverse, it's just "haha big bomb go boom" whose only negative is that it also hits good-guy Godzilla.

I'll watch more eventually. The /wsg/ threads gave me all sorts of clips to get a taste of which ones I'd like and information about the various eras.

>>180057429
Why the fuck are you dying on this hill? I'm on your side. 20,000 Fathoms was released a full year before Gojira even entered production, the idea for Gojira was created by Tomoyuki Tanaka while traveling internationally, assumedly having seen 20,000 Fathoms (which had a MASSIVE theatrical release) along the way. He wrote a short synopsis for a movie titled The Giant Monster from 20,000 Miles Beneath the Sea (海底二万哩から来た大怪獣).
They adapted the idea of a giant prehistoric seamonster emerging from the sea to devastate a major city to fit the greater societal fear of Japanese culture of the day which was having entire cities wiped off the map by unstoppable forces of nuclear power. The end result was something far better than the original, but it was still inspired by it.

All Godzilla movies are good except the Matthew Broderick abomination and the animated shit.

The top 7 in order:
1. Godzilla vs. Monster Zero aka Invasion of Astro-Monster
2. Godzilla vs. Biollante
3. Godzilla (1955 version with Raymond Burr)
4. Godzilla, Mothra, King Ghidorah: Giant Monsters All-Out Attack
5. Godzilla vs. Mechagodzilla (1974)
6. Mothra vs. Godzilla (1964)
7. Godzilla Returns aka Godzilla 1985 (version with Raymond Burr)

In fact, every live action Toho kaiju film is either good or great. Most are great.

>>180060636
Gojira (1954) is without a doubt the closest in tone and while the effects are some of the cheapest in the series they are pretty well covered up with some expert lighting and overall great direction that give it both a very horror and noir vibe
Return Of Godzilla is up there but the effects really have not aged well and the plot is more a commentary on the Cold War which is hard to take seriously nowadays
Godzilla vs Biollante and Godzilla vs Destroyah are fan favorites and without a doubt the next darkest movies in the franchise but still have some cheesy human plots and ultimately feel very much like 80's/90's sci-fi flicks
Honorable mention to Godzilla (2014) for keeping to the incomprehensible/mysterious theme of Godzilla for a fair share of the movie. It also falls into some ridiculous human storylines but the director did a great job of keeping Godzilla as just these massive, lumbering limbs that smashed through smoke and darkness for a lot of the films, which a lot of fans hated but I think it kept to his feeling of being this unknown force of nature.

>>180059622
>>180059878
>whereas the Legendary films have shit the bed hard
>As far as soundtrack
Taking a quick look back at some of the Monsterverse, a humongous part of this is because music has been replaced by SFX. Just looking at the KotM Ghidora resurrection scene, where Godzilla shows up for the first fight, the background music is dim and buried beneath the sheer eat-porn of the monster's SFX. The weight of a foot step, the cracking of ice, the room-shuddering rumble of their bodies colliding, the roars and battlecries, the metal creak of the plane under stress. The music is just a soft hum beneath all the NOISE that's going on in this. It's clearly a very stylistic choice, and it comes across quite well.

Well-composed music laid over all that would have a negative effect on the feeling the audio director was going for. I think that's why they only use the deep horns of the og them song for Godzilla's appearance into a scene, then scale it down to a low hum for the action. I would hardly call it "shitting the bed."

To go after alleged racial discrimination on this level field is one thing, to say that the field isn't level because blacks only just got there is a whole different matter. In that case, affirmative action is a way to unlevel the field again.
I think the confusion comes not from the playing field but from the outcomes. Of course being newer to the game, blacks weren't already incorporated into everything like whites were, they were beginning their incorporation like whites once did. They're similar to immigrants in this regard, who often come with less than blacks have, and statistically are better off than even native born whites are regardless because they aren't disasdvantaged in their opportunity, they just didn't start at the same time.

>"The Yattering and Jack"
>Jack Polo is a gherkin importer who is haunted by a minor demon called the Yattering. >Eventually Jack tricks the Yattering into violating its orders, allowing Jack to take advantage of a loophole and make the Yattering his slave.

>Jacqueline Ess is a housewife who attempts suicide after becoming bored with her life. She recovers only to find that she has an ability to change people's body shapes with her mind. >Jacqueline eventually becomes a prostitute, her abilities giving her the power to give men the ultimate sexual experience, even though one ends up being fatal. Until the rich class president (i forgot the character but it was the guy that creeped everyone out.) he came saying that no one likes the sherif running the human trafficking and they want a coup but they can’t actually do anything, so they’re planning to use Dylan as bait to kill the sheriff. If Dylan kills the sheriff then he’ll spare him and his friend but he’s not going to be an outright ally. Dylan and Kim think it through then they come to a conclusion. posts.com:
>>180061155
To expand on the top 10
>1. The Perfectly Behaved Boy
The best overall (tense) atmosphere with incredibly disciplined pacing
>2. The Devil Game
The best classic campfire story/Halloween atmosphere
>3. White With Red
The best micropasta, and the pasta most efficiently built around a single creepy image
>4. The Smiling Man
Also built very well around creepy imagery, second place candidate for the most plausibly real
>5. Normal Porn for Normal People
Great atmosphere, feels like you're being watched. The greatest possible "Internet horror" story, as it doesn't go too far with it.
>6. Ability
The most uniquely executed twist. Never seen another pasta like this. Not scary, but very novel.
>7. Psychosis
Classic, bats your mind back and forth more effectively than any other
>8. Go Play
Not scary, but the most beautifully written pasta of all time
>9. Pete the Moonshiner
The most jaw-dropping and best overall twist
>10. Wrong Way Charlie
The most brutally, viscerally unpleasant pasta ever. Dare I say, almost exploitative but I don't care. Blue ribbon winner for most likely to be a true story.

I'm a trans individual who has been on /tv/ for years. I've yet to see any definitive proof that anything which is largely accepted by the trans community is bad for them, and I'm here to address these issues.

Let's get a hot topic out of the way first: gender reassignment surgery is as necessary for individuals experiencing severe gender dysphoria as chemo would be for a cancer patient. Yes, some people still unfortunately kill themselves. But, every single person who undergoes surgery who doesnt is a person whose life is saved. It is not cosmetic, it is life saving.

Secondly, estrogen is not bad for your mind or body in any way as an assigned-at-birth male. There is zero scientific evidence that it is. This is baseless and only serves to scare people away from taking the medicine they need

Third: it can be "too late to change". I am 37 and I only began hrt 5 years ago. Within two years I was visually passing and now my voice sounds indistinguishable from any other woman's.

Finally, that it is bad for children to transition. Most children have no issue with this and think it's cool to know a trans individual. And giving children estrogen does in fact make it easier on them psychologically to go through their lives as a woman. There is zero evidence that any child has experienced adverse effects growing up compared to non-trans children.

I will talk to anyone about any of these things. I'm just sick of seeing baseless bullshit spewed about us on this board. Seeing that stuff early on in my transition made me think about some things I never want to think about again. And anyone who posts pictures of girls who are having trouble passing is participating in psychological abuse.

>The plot device employed in Josephine Mutzenbacher is that of first-person narrative, structured in the format of a memoir. The story is told from the point of view of an accomplished aging 50-year-old Viennese courtesan who is looking back upon the sexual escapades she enjoyed during her unbridled youth in Vienna. Contrary to the title, almost the entirety of the book takes place when Josephine is between the ages of 5–13 years old, before she actually becomes a licensed prostitute in the brothels of Vienna.
